title: Parallel Clique Counting and Peeling Algorithms

sections.experiments:
Environment.
We run most of our experiments on a machine with
30 cores (with two-way hyper-threading),
with 3.8GHz Intel Xeon Scalable (Cascade Lake) processors and 240 GiB
of main memory. For our large compressed graphs, we use a machine with
80 cores (with two-way hyper-threading),
with 2.6GHz Intel Xeon E7 (Broadwell E7) processors and 3844 GiB of
main memory. We compile our programs with g++ (version 7.3.1)
using the -O3 flag. We use OpenMP for our k𝑘k-clique counting runtimes, and we use a lightweight scheduler called Homemade
for our k𝑘k-clique peeling runtimes .
We terminate
any experiment that takes over 5 hours, except for experiments on
the large compressed graphs. Graph Inputs. We test our algorithms on real-world
graphs from the Stanford Network Analysis Project
(SNAP) , CMU’s Lemur
project , and the WebDataCommons
dataset [ref]34. The details of the graphs are in Table 1,
and we show additional statistics in the appendix. Algorithm Implementations. We test different
orientations for our counting and peeling algorithms, including the
Goodrich-Pszona and Barenboim-Elkin orientations from Section
3.1, with ε=1𝜀1\varepsilon=1. We
also test other orientations that do not give work-efficient
and polylogarithmic-span bounds, but are fast in
practice, including the orientation given by ranking vertices by
non-decreasing degree, the orientation given by the k𝑘k-core
ordering , and the orientation given by the original
ordering of vertices in the graph. Moreover, we compare our algorithms against
kClist , which contains state-of-the-art parallel
and sequential k𝑘k-clique counting algorithms, and sequential k𝑘k-clique peeling
implementations. kClist additionally includes a parallel
approximate k𝑘k-clique peeling implementation. We include a simple
modification to their k𝑘k-clique counting code to support faster k𝑘k-clique
counting, where we simply return the number of
k𝑘k-cliques instead of iterating over each k𝑘k-clique in the final level of recursion.
kClist also
offers the option of node or edge parallelism, but only offers a
k𝑘k-core ordering to orient the input graphs. Note that
kClist does not offer a choice of orientation. We additionally compare our counting algorithms to Jain and
Seshadhri’s Pivoter algorithm , Mhedhbi and
Salihoglu’s worst-case optimal join algorithm
(WCO) , Lai et al.’s implementation of a
binary join algorithm (BinaryJoin) , and Pinar
et al.’s ESCAPE algorithm . Note
that Pivoter is designed for counting all cliques, and the latter
three algorithms are designed for general subgraph counting. Finally, we
compare our approximate k𝑘k-clique counting algorithm to Bressan et
al.’s MOTIVO algorithm for approximate subgraph
counting , which is more general. For k𝑘k-clique peeling,
we compare to Fang et al.’s CoreApp
algorithm  and Tsourakakis’s 
triangle densest subgraph implementation.
